Hi,

I have read your post. And I have the question: Is it possible to 
set=
 the enthalpy? And how can I do it?
I don't find the equivalent of mix.setT=
emperature but for enthalpy 
(a syntax like mix.setEnthalpy(H) but it doesn=
't work).
My work is to generate FPI tables with a third coordinate 
(entha=
lpy). So I have to know how CANTERA is able to simulate 
equilibrium at dif=
ferent level of enthalpy (from adiabatic limit to 
quenching limit). 
Could=
 you help me?

Thanks in advance

Regards, David

--- In cantera@yahoogroup=
s.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@...> wrote:
>
> 
> One option is to write an=
 outer loop that iterates on T until the 
> desired H is attained.  A Newto=
n-like algorithm would probably 
converge 
> very quickly.
> 
> With the ne=
w equilibrium solver, it is possible to supply an 
initial 
> guess.  But t=
his hasn't made its way into the released version.  
The 
> issue is entire=
ly one of my finding the time to work on this and 
other 
> desired new fea=
tures.  Cantera has grown beyond a one-person 
> development effort, and my=
 backlog of non-Cantera commitments is 
going 
> to keep me from devoting m=
uch time to it for the next few weeks at 
> least.
> 
> I'm not entirely su=
re what to do about this general problem.  One 
> possibility would be for =
users to make voluntary cash donations 
that I 
> could use to hire some pr=
ogramming help to provide faster response 
to 
> requests for new features,=
 bug fixes, etc. There is currently a 
> mechanism in place through sourcef=
orge where you can donate to 
this 
> project.  All donations will be accep=
ted, no matter how small (or 
> large), and all will be used solely for fur=
thering Cantera 
development. 
>   You even get your name listed on the web=
 site as a Cantera 
supporter!
> 
> Or perhaps there are other ways to do t=
his.  Since Cantera is 
> open-source, if any of you have idle programming =
talent at your 
> company, lab, or university, I'd be happy to provide dire=
ction on 
what 
> needs doing...
> 
>   If anyone has thoughts on this, ple=
ase let me know.
> 
> Dave
